title.narrative: YBM - Land Right for Marginalised - ID

description.narrative:
Project named #Right to Land for Marginalized People# aim to increase community#s resilience in 6 villages in Sumba through sustainable social capacity. Its expected outcome: 1) Marginalized community (the servant caste, incomer, and poor households # particularly households headed by women) get access to and control of cultivation land as long-term household income; and 2) Implementation of natural resource management in the village, with sustainable social political support.
The idea regarding to the recent situation of villages in Sumba Tengah and Sumba Timur Districts, where most of the land is owned by Maramba caste (the aristocrats) and passed by inheritance. People of the lowest caste, Ata (the servants), as well as incomer and other poor community have no access to the cultivation land. The servant caste is exploited as laborers without the right of benefit from the land they manage, depending their lives on the #mercy# of the master. In addition, community land in some villages are #claimed# as national park or industrial plantation, limiting access for those who depends on forest for subsistence.
Despite the large area of unused land in Sumba, particularly Sumba Timur and Sumba Tengah, poverty, malnutrition, and low food security still haunting. This is worsened by the strong social caste system. In general Sumba culture knows 3 social classes, namely Maramba (the aristocrats), Kabihu (the ordinary people), and Ata (the servant) # this social status is inherited. According to Kal Muller (1997), the social hierarchy in Sumba Tengah and Sumba Timur is still rigid. There#s a sharp contrast between the Maramba and Ata caste, the first has full control in economically, socially, and culturally through external and internal authority and institution, while the latter fully depends on the first. For the Maramba, servants are a symbol of status, although exploiting and escaping the responsibility to take care of their lives is a common practice.
In public sphere, these marginalized people haveno opportunity to pose different opinion in front of the master or in open forum. They are also considered not knowledgable to make decision, thus rarely get important position in the village. Women, wether they are from Ata caste, incomer, or poor households, are the most marginalized. Women servants are vulnerable to violence from both male and female from upper caste. In addition, polygamy culture is rampant, in which husbands can marry other women without consent from their wife. The project is expected to initiate policy change, both on customary law level as well as state law, to ensure equal access to land and its harvest for every villager, including women as head of household. The method consisted of awareness building,negotiation, and conflictmediation, so that all stakeholders agree to open access to land. Among the tools utilized is participatory mapping of land boundary, status, ownership, and its allocation.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to social and political participation
